Summary I am one of the earliest business quantitative analyst hired to focus on Google Play's user behavior and modeling their life time value. With huge amount of users across the world, Play is a very unique platform with both paid and free transaction, which created a very interesting but also challenging data to work on. I work very closely with PM and Engineer team to build model to predict the life time value of Play users using advanced statistical models. 
 
I also have significant experience on business planing and strategy, especially using data and visualization to provide insight to the business when working at Google's Biz Ops & Strategy team in Sales. With strong communication and presenting skills, many of my analytic results and presentations were presented and shared to Google's VPs and management group and had significant impact to the business and decision making.  
 
Specialties: Extensive knowledge in machine learning and data mining (Random Forest, Lasso, Gradient Boosting, Logistic Regression, Variable Selection, CART ), business strategies and plans, R programming, data visualization, statistical predictive models Summary I am one of the earliest business quantitative analyst hired to focus on Google Play's user behavior and modeling their life time value. Summary Elizabeth Gonzalez is a Ph. D. candidate in the Department of Psychology at the University of California, Santa Cruz. Elizabeth's research examines the ethnic-racial identity development and academic adjustment of ethnic-racial minority and (im)migrant youth. Her current work examines the emotions evoked by discrimination, in particular shame, anger, and pride, and their relationship to the ethnic-racial attitudes of Indigenous Mexican adolescents and young adults. Her previous work examined the emotions and ambiguous loss experienced by Latino youth following the deportation of a parent. Elizabeth has been a recipient of the Ford Foundation Pre-Doctoral Fellowship, the Eugene Cota-Robles Fellowship, UC MEXUS Research Grant award, and the Chicano Latino Research Center Graduate Student Mini-Grant at UC Santa Cruz.  
 
Elizabeth situates her research within community-based participatory action research (CBPAR), an innovative methodology where researchers collaborate with community members to take actions that address social problems. Under this framework, in 2011, Elizabeth collaborated with high school students, teachers, and school administrators to establish RAICES Indígenas de Mexico, a student club aimed at providing a safe space for students to discuss strategies for dealing with discrimination against Indigenous Mexican adolescents and promoting knowledge of the Indigenous cultures of Mexico. RAICES is now an official student club at one high school and one middle school, with plans to expand to additional school (see Santa Cruz Sentinel article). Summary Elizabeth Gonzalez is a Ph. Experience Program Coordinator Educational Opportunity Programs September 2013  – Present (2 years) University of California, Santa Cruz The Pathways to Research Program (P2R), offered by UCSC's Educational Opportunities Program, is an individualized two-quarter research intensive program for EOP students in the Humanities and Social Sciences. P2R is designed for undergraduate students interested in building exposure and an action plan to engage in rigorous undergraduate level research and apply to the best graduate school programs. As P2R Coordinator and mentor, Elizabeth's responsibilities include: consulting for program's grant proposal, hiring a team of 5 Graduate Student Mentors (Ph.D. students)- each assigned to mentor a group of 5 students; facilitating P2R informational workshops and presentations across the UCSC campus; leading the selection process for 40-50 highly qualified undergraduate students dedicated to exploring and engaging in academic research; mentoring students with their research and graduate school exploration/application process; collecting and analyzing program evaluations form mentors and mentees; and coordinating program welcome and closing ceremony events. Instructor UC Santa Cruz June 2013  – Present (2 years 3 months) Instructor for Psychology 102: Adolescent Development, an upper-division undergraduate summer course at UCSC. This course focuses on individual and relational development from early adolescence to emerging adulthood. We discuss the mutual influences and contexts of biology, cognition, family, peers, school, and culture. Special topics include: identity development of ethnic-racial minority and immigrant youth; the impact of migration on adolescent cognition, identity, and relationships. The course draws upon developmental psychology perspective, but other disciplines, including sociology, education, and anthropology are represented. Literature and film are used to illustrate course concepts. As a graduate mentor, Elizabeth worked closely with 5 undergraduate student to develop and execute goals for a two-quarter research intensive program. School 2001  – 2005 San Marcos High School 2001  – 2005 Honors & Awards UC MEXUS Research Grant February 2011 The University of California Institute for Mexico and the United States (UC MEXUS), established in 1980, is an academic research institute dedicated to encouraging, securing, and contributing to binational and Latino research and collaborative academic programs and exchanges. Our main focus is to contribute substantially to improving binational scholarly understanding and providing positive contributions to society in both Mexico and the United States, particularly in the graduate and professional areas. Ford Foundation Pre-Doctoral Fellowship Ford Foundation 2009 Predoctoral fellowships are awarded in a national competition administered by the National Research Council (NRC) on behalf of the Ford Foundation. The awards are made to individuals who, in the judgment of the review panels, have demonstrated superior academic achievement, are committed to a career in teaching and research at the college or university level, show promise of future achievement as scholars and teachers, and are well prepared to use diversity as a resource for enriching the education of all students.  Eugene V. Cota-Robles Fellowship 2009 The Eugene Cota‐Robles (ECR) Fellowship Program, initiated in 1989‐90, provides mentored fellowship support to students who are enrolled in doctoral programs at the University. A particular objective of the ECR Fellowship Program is to release recipients from employment or loan obligations that might delay progress in graduate study during their first years of graduate study.  
 
ECR Fellowships is awarded competitively by the campus graduate divisions. Each recipient is expected to work closely with a faculty sponsor whose role will be that of mentor, guiding the graduate student through the development of a curricular plan, and the acquisition of knowledge and skills that will permit the selection of an appropriate dissertation topic leading to the completion of a doctoral degree. Founder & CEO GOcase October 2012  – Present (2 years 11 months) Miami Beach, FL GOcase designs next level electronics accessories, with a growing line of products available in over 500 retail stores worldwide, as well as a variety of online retailers. 
 
I founded GOcase with the vision of creating premium cases for cutting-edge products in niche markets, and now direct strategy and manage a team at a high level, with a GM recently hired to handle all day-to-day ops.  
 
With a commitment to providing superior product design, quality of materials, and customer service, each GOcase product is designed to be best in class in both form and function. By using the highest quality materials available and emphasizing stylish yet functional design, GOcase makes cases you want to own for the devices you have to have. 
 
GOcase is currently distributed worldwide at a variety of the top consumer electronics retailers in the world. Principal Anthropos Consulting October 2008  – Present (6 years 11 months) Founder of Anthropos Consulting, a boutique helping clients understand and measure the interaction between people, products, and business outcomes in order to drive sustainable growth. Specialties include: 
 
- Improving user experience, engagement, retention, and monetization 
- Product and service design, optimization, and management 
- Measuring, maintaining and building customer loyalty 
- Market and competitive research and intelligence 
- Gamification, viral design, and game mechanics, balance, and economy 
 
Currently specialize in consulting social games and mobile applications, but have extensive vertical experience in management and market research consulting, as well as customer loyalty and user analytics. Research Manager, Player Insights Zynga October 2010  –  October 2012  (2 years 1 month) San Francisco, CA I joined Zynga to help institutionalize the company's Net Promoter customer loyalty program and evangelize it across studios. I then took over all research for Zynga Poker in order to drive NPS to record-highs in the Company. Working with cross-functional teams, I helped conduct design research, A/B testing, customer heat testing, rapid iterated testing, usability testing, play sessions, and customer ethnography. 
 
I subsequently managed Zynga's Benchmarking and diagnostics program, which evaluates all Zynga new IP prior to launch, as well as partner and key competitor products. By linking survey and in-game data to concrete operational and business metrics, I delivered actionable recommendations about strategy and feature development to partner studios, as well as third party developers. Recently transitioned from a full-time consultant to a contract consultant via my consulting firm, Anthropos LLC, in order to further develop that enterprise. Research Consultant Stanford University September 2008  –  January 2010  (1 year 5 months) Managing a research project as a Visiting Scholar at the Stanford Institute for the Quantitative Study of Society in conjunction with the Department of Anthropology.

Summary I’m broadly interested in social cognition, its neural underpinnings, and related change dynamics. More specifically, I focus on the interplay between processes involved in self perception and the perception of others (person perception), with an emphasis on examining development and individual differences. In one line of research, I’m working to understand social influences and biological substrates of pro-social and risky decision making during adolescence. A second line of research investigates predictors of change in personality over the lifespan. Prior work has focused on the neural basis of empathy development during the biological and social transition to adolescence. 
 
Computationally intensive analytic techniques are instrumental for learning about processes of change from large data sets. Tools I employ include multilevel modeling, structural equation modeling, machine learning, and neuroimaging. Beyond my own work, I am dedicated to supporting sound methodology broadly at the University of Oregon — I’m a regular contributor to the department's R Club (a statistical programming consulting and tutorial group), as well as the Bayesian statics seminar.
